#merge two data frame
df = pd.merge(df,df_locations,on='location',how='left')
#drop unwanted columns
df.drop(['iso_code_y','last_observation_date','source_name','source_website'],axis=1,inplace=True)

source.c4615763:
#Filling ISO-3 Codes
df['iso_code'] = df['iso_code'].fillna(pd.Series(np.where(df['location'] == 'England', 'GBR', 'NaN')))
df['iso_code'] = df['iso_code'].fillna(pd.Series(np.where(df['location'] == 'Northern Ireland', 'GBR', 'NaN')))
df['iso_code'] = df['iso_code'].fillna(pd.Series(np.where(df['location'] == 'Scotland', 'GBR', 'NaN')))
df['iso_code'] = df['iso_code'].fillna(pd.Series(np.where(df['location'] == 'Wales', 'GBR', 'NaN')))
df['iso_code'] = df['iso_code'].fillna(pd.Series(np.where(df['location'] == 'Northern Cyprus', 'TUR', 'NaN')))
source.f067a117:
#Date Splitting
yseries = df['date'].map(lambda str: dt.datetime.strptime(str, '%Y-%m-%d').strftime('%Y'))
mseries = df['date'].map(lambda str: dt.datetime.strptime(str, '%Y-%m-%d').strftime('%m'))
dseries = df['date'].map(lambda str: dt.datetime.strptime(str, '%Y-%m-%d').strftime('%d'))

year=[]
month=[]
day=[]

for i in yseries.tolist():
    year.append(int(i))
for i in mseries.tolist():
    month.append(int(i))
for i in dseries.tolist():
    day.append(int(i))

df = pd.DataFrame({'location':df['location'],'iso_code':df['iso_code'],'date':df['date'],'year' : year, 'month' : month,'day':day,
                    'total_vaccinations':df['total_vaccinations'],'people_vaccinated':df['people_vaccinated'],
                    'people_fully_vaccinated':df['people_fully_vaccinated'],'daily_vaccinations_raw':df['daily_vaccinations_raw'],
                    'daily_vaccinations':df['daily_vaccinations'],'total_vaccinations_per_hundred':df['total_vaccinations_per_hundred'],
                    'people_vaccinated_per_hundred':df['people_vaccinated_per_hundred'],'people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred':df['people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred'],
                   'daily_vaccinations_per_million':df['daily_vaccinations_per_million'],'vaccines':df['vaccines']})

### Data Wrangling In this project, My cleaning and wrangling activities included: 1. Join two data frames:
My aim is just getting vaccines' names from df_locations, based on that I joined two data frames 1. Deleting unwanted columns and rename column Iso:
I am not interest in last_observation_date, source_name and website and also iso_code_y is same with iso_code_x, so I dropped iso_code_y and changed other one's name as 'iso_code'. There were two last row, it cause missing value in location so I dropped it.
source.0d75466f:
### 3. In which country the vaccination programme is more advanced?
- Where are vaccinated more people per day? But in terms of a percent from the entire population?
- What country is vaccinated more people? What country is vaccinated a larger percentage of its population?
**Why?**
Another one of the important question is which country can vaccinate their citiziens fastly. It is like vaccine producer countries can be faster, but lets look at the results! **How I did?**
Again, because its time series data set, I created three time series plot to compare each other. Also before creation of the chart, I create two new variable to find portion of how many percentage of population vaccined. I used total vaccination numbers and fully vacinated number from vaccination data set, and divided population that is from covid10 data set. After this process, I put daily vaccinations number, vaccinated population, and fully vaccinated of population (the people who got two doses of vaccine) in row. And, I use date (daily) in column. Also, I added location as a filter, so you can easily play with data. To make simplify, I choose first four countries that are nearly first for each categories. **Results**
According to daily vaccination numbers in February, it looks like the USA and UK have the highest daily vaccination. On the other hand, Israel is remarkably fast than other countries, in the date of February 4, 2021, Isreal has finished nearly 60% of the population at least the first doses of vaccine and nearly 22% of its population got both two doses.
After Israel, United Arab Emirates also has finished nearly 40% of the population at least first doses of vaccine but its full vaccinations numbers still behind. After these countries, while the UK has finished nearly 16% of the population, the USA has finished nearly 10% of the population at least first doses of vaccine. Even if the other countries have low numbers, data is very changeable day by day.

> # COVID-19 World Vaccination Progress 💉 ![](https://wp.technologyreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/SO20_vaccines_FF_02-web.jpg?w=500) [Source of Picture](https://wp.technologyreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/SO20_vaccines_FF_02-web.jpg?w=500) _Vaccines typically require years of research and testing before reaching the clinic, but in 2020, scientists embarked on a race to produce safe and effective coronavirus vaccines in record time. Researchers are currently testing 67 vaccines in clinical trials on humans, and 20 have reached the final stages of testing. At least 89 preclinical vaccines are under active investigation in animals. The Vaccines that are used all around the world now: (02.02.2021)_

|VACCINE COMPANY| VACCINE NAME| EFFICACY| DOSE | TYPE | STORAGE| |--- | --- |--- | --- | --- | ---| |Pfizer/BioNTech |Comirnaty |95% | 2 doses, 3 weeks apart | Muscle injection | Freezer storage only at –94°F (–70°C)| |Moderna |mRNA-1273 | 94.5% | 2 doses, 4 weeks apart| Muscle injection | 30 days with refrigeration, 6 months at –4°F (–20°C)| |The Gamaleya Research Institute|Sputnik V | 91.4% |2 doses, 3 weeks apart| Muscle injection | Freezer storage. Developing an alternative formulation that can be refrigerated.| |Oxford/AstraZeneca|AZD1222 | 62% to 90%, depending on dosage |2 doses, 4 weeks apart| Muscle injection | Stable in refrigerator for at least 6 months| |Sinopharm|BBIBP-CorV | 79.34% |2 doses, 3 weeks apart| Muscle injection | | |Sinovac|CoronaVac| 50.38% |2 doses, 2 weeks apart| Muscle injection | Refrigerated | |Bharat Biotech|Covaxin| Unknown |2 doses, 4 weeks apart| Muscle injection | At least a week at room temperature | [source: The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/science/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker.html)

1. What is the vaccine distribution? Are there any decreases in the number of cases in the countries that begin the vaccination process?
1. In which country the vaccination programme is more advanced?
- Where are vaccinated more people per day? But in terms of a percent from the entire population?
- What country is vaccinated more people? What country is vaccinated a larger percentage of its population?
1. After the beginning of the vaccine process all around the world, how the infection trend moves?
1. Are there any correlations between the factors of development indicators and the numbers of vaccinations?
source.8b935446:
### 4. After the beginning of the vaccine process all around the world, how the infection trend moves?
**Why?**
Even if the vaccination process is in the early stage, the most wondered question is how this process has been affected world covid case and death numbers, is there a light at the end of the tunnel? **How I did?**
In this question, again I used both data set for the creation of time series charts. Firstly, to show the last picture of Covid-19 numbers, I added 'Total cases', 'Total deaths', 'New cases Smoothed' and 'New Deaths Smoothed' in rows, and daily in the column. For the location, I filtered by just choosing 'World' data. In the same way, in the below line chart, I used world data and total vaccination numbers. I also added map of total vaccination all around the world, however differences of the USA, China and rest of the world is very big, the colour of other countries cannot distinguishable. **Results**
From the first two line charts, it seems to be total cases and total deaths near to reach the highest level. And fortunately, the daily case numbers look like decreasing even if the number of deaths does not show the same trend, we can say that the death numbers didn't increase remarkably in the last months. The below chart, clearly shows that number of vaccinations is increasing rapidly. While the case number reach 103M in one year period, the vaccination number reach the same number in nearly two months period. As of 2 February 2021, the total cases are 103,137,905 and the total vaccinations are 105,115,442. Even if the total vaccinations still include a small portion of the world, it looks like that an important portion of the world population can be vaccinated within a year if it continue to increase with this fast.
source.a95d4ce1: [Click for the big version of the graph.](https://public.tableau.com/views/World_16126333851160/Q4?:language=en&:display_count=y&publish=yes&:origin=viz_share_link)
source.d2de2a28:
# Conclusion There is a light at the end of the tunnel! Even if there is a very early stage of the vaccination process, according to this analysis result, I expect that the declining number of covid-19 cases and the followingly the decline of the number of the deaths. I hope that the vaccination production process continues as fast as possible until each citizen who wants to be vaccinated can reach it.

On the other hand, with this number and this length of time, it is impossible to say which vaccine effective than others. However, I put the efficiency of each vaccine that I got from the New York Times web page in the introduction. we can see the real efficiency of the vaccines after at least half of the population gets vaccinated.

I tried to visualize each question as clearly as possible, If you have any doubt about it or anything you think that unclear about this analysis, I happy to clarify. Please write your comments!
I will try to update it frequently!

source.249d0069:
Understanding missing values

1. The iso-codes that are used for these countries : 'England','Northern Ireland','Scotland', 'Wales' are actually 'United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland' and iso_code of them is 'GBR'[source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3). 'European Union' does not have any 3 letters iso_code, and 'Northern Cyprus' is actually dependent country of Turkey so it's code: 'TUR'.
1. The other missing values are related some countries begin to vaccinations later than other countries and the process is counting so I didnt do anything for them.
1. For playing with date base data, I splitted date, year, month and day. Also I added new columns for each of them.

source.0aa7e63b:
### 2. What is the vaccine distribution? Are there any decreases in the number of cases in the countries that begin the vaccination process?
**Why?**
After finding which vaccines are commonly used, the other wondering question is 'Are they really help to reduce the cases and deaths?'. Even if lots of factor affects the cases and deaths number, everyone hopes after vaccinations, the numbers will remarkably decrease. Vaccinations began in December of 2020 and the process has still continued. Even if nearly just 2 months passed after the vaccination process, I tried to compare the daily vaccinations number, which vaccines are commonly used. And also is there any clear effect on decreases number? **How I did?**
I prepared a bar chart as I mentioned above. And for the boxplot, I used each daily vaccinations in a row and date in a column. And because 2020 has lots of null values, I used just data of 2021 by filtering date. For the bottom line graph, firstly, I merged two data sets (df_vaccinations and df_covid) to use cases and death numbers. I use locations (countries) as a key. After that, I created daily base time series for daily cases and death numbers. And, to avoid noises in the time series, I used smoothed variables. These variables are prepared by getting each 7-day average period. Finally, I used vaccines as a filter, you can play with data by clicking which vaccines effect you want to see. **Results**
Firstly, I want to mention daily vaccinations. As you can see from the box-plot, all daily vaccinations numbers among 500k and 0k because most countries still have struggled to supply the vaccine. On the other hand, CNBG, Sinovac distribution looks very balanced and nearly between 500k and 1000k. The reason for that, actually is China's distribution, only China has used this combination and also both CNBG(Sinopharm) and Sinovac have been produced in China. On the other hand, Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech combination is widely used, so there are lots of outliers. The bar graph shows that Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech combination is the highest commonly used vaccines. So, when we select this combination from the line chart below, we can clearly see after mid-January case numbers began to decline. Even if the death numbers have been going to stable. When I looked at each vaccine, the numbers going down or at least they are stable. So, maybe we can say that the vaccination process works for now.
source.918582f1: Now, to play data in tableau, I got this file as a csv file.
source.aa1df3f5:
### Gathering Data Data sets distributed by [Our World in Data](https://github.com/owid/covid-19-data/tree/master/public/data) is publicly available. (Because the same kaggle data set combined with inner join, it lost some information The data covers daily vaccinations number from 13 December 2020 to up to date. The frequency of dissemination and Release calendar of the data is the daily base. The formats are a comma-separated value (CSV) file, has the tabular format. #### Global vaccination data:
Country metadata
Column Description
location name of the country (or region within a country)
iso_code ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 – three-letter country codes
vaccines list of vaccines administered in the country up to the current date
last_observation_date date of the last observation in our data
source_name name of our source for data collection
source_website web location of our source. It can be a standard URL if numbers are consistently reported on a given page; otherwise it will be the source for the last data point

Vaccination data
Column Description
location name of the country (or region within a country)
iso_code ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 – three-letter country codes
date date of the observation
total_vaccinations total number of doses administered. This is counted as a single dose, and may not equal the total number of people vaccinated, depending on the specific dose regime (e.g. people receive multiple doses). If a person receives one dose of the vaccine, this metric goes up by 1. If they receive a second dose, it goes up by 1 again
total_vaccinations_per_hundred total_vaccinations per 100 people in the total population of the country
daily_vaccinations_raw daily change in the total number of doses administered. It is only calculated for consecutive days. This is a raw measure provided for data checks and transparency, but we strongly recommend that any analysis on daily vaccination rates be conducted using daily_vaccinations instead
daily_vaccinations new doses administered per day (7-day smoothed). For countries that don't report data on a daily basis, we assume that doses changed equally on a daily basis over any periods in which no data was reported. This produces a complete series of daily figures, which is then averaged over a rolling 7-day window
daily_vaccinations_per_million daily_vaccinations per 1,000,000 people in the total population of the country
people_vaccinated total number of people who received at least one vaccine dose. If a person receives the first dose of a 2-dose vaccine, this metric goes up by 1. If they receive the second dose, the metric stays the same
people_vaccinated_per_hundred people_vaccinated per 100 people in the total population of the country
people_fully_vaccinated total number of people who received all doses prescribed by the vaccination protocol. If a person receives the first dose of a 2-dose vaccine, this metric stays the same. If they receive the second dose, the metric goes up by 1
people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred people_fully_vaccinated per 100 people in the total population of the country

**Note**: for people_vaccinated and people_fully_vaccinated we are dependent on the necessary data being made available, so we may not be able to make these metrics available for some countries.

#### Data on COVID-19 (coronavirus) by Our World in Data:
Data on COVID-19 This data sets contains 60 different variables. I explained the variables that I used in this analysis.
Column Source Description
iso_code International Organization for Standardization ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 – three-letter country codes
location Our World in Data Geographical location
date Our World in Data Date of observation
total_cases COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University Total confirmed cases of COVID-19
new_cases COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University New confirmed cases of COVID-19
new_cases_smoothed COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University New confirmed cases of COVID-19 (7-day smoothed)
total_deaths COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University Total deaths attributed to COVID-19
new_deaths COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University New deaths attributed to COVID-19
new_deaths_smoothed COVID-19 Data Repository by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University New deaths attributed to COVID-19 (7-day smoothed)
population United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, World Population Prospects 2019 Revision Population in 2020
population_density World Bank World Development Indicators, sourced from Food and Agriculture Organization and World Bank estimates Number of people divided by land area, measured in square kilometers, most recent year available
gdp_per_capita World Bank World Development Indicators, source from World Bank, International Comparison Program database Gross domestic product at purchasing power parity (constant 2011 international dollars), most recent year available
life_expectancy James C. Riley, Clio Infra, United Nations Population Division Life expectancy at birth in 2019
human_development_index United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, being knowledgeable and have a decent standard of living
source.c33f30f6: ## Methodology I will use python libraries within the Kaggle notebook environment for investigation these questions. The main software libraries I’ll be importing are Pandas, NumPy for data wrangling. I will also add Tableau visualizations.
source.d0166971:
### 1. Which country is using what vaccine or What vaccines are used and in which countries?
**Why?**
It is clear while the Covid-19 pandemic has been resuming, the last days' new vaccination process is a hot topic all around the world. And one of the most wondering topics is which country are using which vaccines. **How I did?**
After the data wrangling in here, I got the output of this CSV file and imported this file tableau public version. Firstly, I assigned location and iso_code variables Geographical role as a country and iso code. Then, I created a new worksheet, when I double-clicked on location, the map automatically created. Then, I put vaccines in colour and the sum of Daily Vaccinations Raw in size. Finally, I changed the colour of Vaccines to follow easier, I used blue colours for Oxford/AstraZeneca groups, greens for Pfizer/BioNtech, reds for Sinovac and orange for Sputnik V. And I created the bottom left bar chart in another sheet. I put locations in a row and the sum of Daily Vaccinations Raw in the column. Again I put vaccines in colour, and the same colours appeared automatically.Then, I created the bottom right bar chart using the count of countries and vaccines' names. Lastly, I created a dashboard put these three sheets in it. Then, I save the tableau public, got embedded codes of HTML to use in Kaggle. **Results**
Because generally, countries have not used just one kind of vaccine, it is hard to find which country uses what vaccines. However, it seems lots of countries have used at least some Pfizer/BioNTech's combinations, As you can see on the map green colours appear mostly on the map and the size of greens also bigger than others generally. Also, when we look at the right bottom graph, Pfizer/BioNTech and combinations are using the majority of countries, especially by European and North American countries. Even if there is no country just using Moderna, Countries that have higher total vaccination numbers are using Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech combination like USA, Isreal, Germany. Next, maybe we can mention Oxford/AstraZeneca, while 6 countries are using this vaccine, 9 countries are using a combination of it. Again, Countries that have higher total vaccination numbers are using Oxford/AstraZeneca combinations like UK, India, Brazil. Followingly, Sinovac is another vaccine commonly used. The countries that have higher total vaccination numbers like China, Brazil and Turkey are using Sinovac and its combinations. If we mention Sinopharm, Egypt has been using just Sinopharm, but the vaccination number of Egypt is very low. 4 countries have been using a combination of Sinopharm and one of the countries is the United Arab Emirates the 6th of the highest vaccination number. Finally, Sputnik V has been used commonly by Russia and other 3 countries, but the numbers of it are lower than other vaccines. Also, Covaxin has been using by Just India with Oxford/AstraZeneca.
source.fee72afd:
### 5. Are there any correlations between the factors of development indicators and the numbers of vaccinations?
**Why?**
In this question, I eximaned if is there any realationship countries development indicators and their vaccination process. For example, I thought if getting vaccination fastly is related money, we should see clear correlation between vaccination numbers and Gdp per capita. Let's see. **How I did?**
I used 'Human Development Index', 'Population Density', 'Life Expectancy' and 'Gdp Per Capita' from the covid data set, and 'Total Vaccinations' from the vaccination data set. All explanations and sources of these variables explained 'Gathering Data' section. Creating this correlation graph quite easy in Tableau. I added the same variables both in rows and columns. Also, I made adjustments in the axis about scaling, for example, life expectancy began with zero, I changed this number with minimum life expectancy. Finally, I added locations as a filter. You can also play with countries, the result can change when you deselect the dominant country. **Results**
for my analysis, I looked at the total vaccination row. Unfortunately, there is no clear correlation between vaccination numbers and other variables. However, vaccination numbers still include a very very small portion of the world, I quite expect that this graph will be changed while the numbers increases. When I played with locations, in some cases I realized that there's a low correlation between vaccinations and GDP per capita.
